Data Representation Passage: 3 figures showing temperature vs. pressure relationships → Use figure-first approach, spend 60+ seconds examining graphs, minimal text reading

Research Summaries Passage: 3 experiments with detailed procedures and result tables → Use figure-first but allocate more time to skimming experimental descriptions

Conflicting Viewpoints Passage: Scientists A and B debate climate change mechanisms → Read text more thoroughly to understand each perspective, but still check figures for supporting evidence

Experiment with different approaches during practice to find what maximizes your accuracy and speed.

3. Efficient Figure and Table Analysis Techniques

Since figures and tables contain the majority of information needed to answer Science questions, developing systematic figure analysis skills is essential. Learning to extract key information quickly and accurately from visual data representations will dramatically improve both your speed and accuracy on the Science section.

The Five-Element Figure Analysis Framework

When you look at any figure, systematically check five elements: (1) Variables - What is being measured or manipulated? Read all axis labels and table headers. (2) Units - What units are used for each variable? (meters, grams, seconds, etc.) Pay attention to unit prefixes like "k" for kilo or "m" for milli. (3) Scale - What range of values is shown? Does the axis start at zero or some other value? Is the scale linear or logarithmic? (4) Trends - How do the variables relate to each other? Do values increase together (positive correlation), move in opposite directions (inverse relationship), or show no clear pattern? (5) Legend/Key - What do different lines, symbols, colors, or categories represent? Making this five-element check habitual ensures you never miss important details that could cause errors.

Common Figure Types and How to Read Them

ACT Science passages use several standard figure types, each requiring slightly different reading strategies. Line graphs show how one variable changes with another; focus on the overall trend (increasing, decreasing, constant) and whether the relationship is linear or curved. Bar graphs compare values across categories; look for which category has the highest or lowest value and how much they differ. Scatter plots show relationships between two variables with individual data points; look for general patterns or clusters. Data tables organize values in rows and columns; identify what each row and column represents and notice patterns as you move across rows or down columns. Diagrams illustrate experimental setups or scientific processes; understand what each labeled component represents and how they interact. Recognizing these common types helps you quickly orient yourself and know what to look for.

Identifying Trends and Relationships

Many Science questions ask about trends and relationships between variables. When examining figures, actively ask yourself: How do the variables relate? Common relationship types include: positive/direct relationship (both variables increase together), negative/inverse relationship (one increases while the other decreases), no relationship (changes in one variable don't affect the other), linear relationship (the relationship forms a straight line), non-linear relationship (the relationship is curved), and exponential relationship (the rate of change accelerates). Being able to quickly identify these relationship types allows you to answer trend questions without needing to read specific values. You should also notice whether trends are consistent across the entire range shown or whether the relationship changes at certain points.

Avoiding Common Figure-Reading Mistakes

Several common errors can lead to wrong answers even when you understand the science conceptually. Confusing x and y variables is extremely common—always check which variable is on which axis. Misreading scales causes many errors, especially when axes don't start at zero or use non-standard intervals (like going 0, 50, 100, 200, 500 instead of evenly spaced values). Ignoring units can lead to errors when comparing values from different figures or when units change within a passage. Misidentifying which line or symbol represents which condition is another frequent mistake—always double-check the legend. Extrapolating too far beyond the data shown can also cause errors—be cautious when predicting values outside the measured range. Slowing down for just 2-3 extra seconds to verify these details prevents careless mistakes that cost points.

Example: Systematic Figure Analysis

Figure 1: Graph showing "Temperature (°C)" on x-axis and "Reaction Rate (mol/sec)" on y-axis

Variables: Temperature and Reaction Rate
Units: Temperature in °C, Reaction Rate in mol/sec
Scale: x-axis goes from 0-80°C in intervals of 20; y-axis goes from 0-5 mol/sec in intervals of 1
Trend: As temperature increases, reaction rate increases (positive relationship, appears to be exponential)
Legend: One line shown, labeled "Enzyme A"

This 15-second analysis prepares you to answer most questions about this figure without needing to re-examine it repeatedly.

4. Maximizing Efficiency Through Strategic Passage Selection

Not all Science passages are equally difficult, and you don't have to complete them in the order they appear. Strategic passage selection—choosing which passages to tackle first based on your strengths and passage characteristics—can significantly improve your score by ensuring you maximize points earned within the time limit and maintain confidence and momentum throughout the section.

Identifying Your Strongest Passage Types

Through practice, you should identify which passage types you find easiest and most time-efficient. Many students find Data Representation passages quickest because they have minimal text and straightforward graph-reading questions. Others prefer Research Summaries passages because they enjoy the logical structure of experimental design. Some students find Conflicting Viewpoints passages most accessible because they involve reading comprehension skills similar to the Reading section. Understanding your preferences allows you to develop a personalized passage order strategy. For example, if you're strongest at Data Representation, you might quickly flip through the section at the start, identify the 2-3 Data Representation passages by their figure-heavy layouts, and complete those first. This approach ensures you secure easy points quickly and build confidence before tackling more challenging passages.

Quick Passage Previewing Technique

At the start of the Science section, consider spending 30-45 seconds doing a quick preview of all passages to identify which look most straightforward. Flip through and quickly assess: (1) How many figures does each passage have? Passages with more complex or dense figures may take longer. (2) How much text is present? Text-heavy passages (usually Conflicting Viewpoints) may require more reading time. (3) Do any passages cover topics you're familiar with? While outside knowledge isn't required, comfort with a topic can boost confidence. (4) Are there any passages with particularly simple-looking graphs or tables? These might be quick wins. Based on this preview, mentally rank the passages from most to least approachable and tackle them in that order. However, be careful not to spend too much time previewing—if this takes more than 45 seconds, it's probably not worth it. Some students prefer to just start with the first passage rather than risk wasting time on decision-making.

Banking Time with Faster Passages

The strategy of completing easier passages first has another advantage: banking time for more difficult passages. If you can complete a straightforward Data Representation passage in 3.5 minutes instead of 5 minutes, you've saved 1.5 minutes that you can apply to a more complex Research Summaries or Conflicting Viewpoints passage later. This flexibility is crucial because some passages genuinely do take longer than others due to complexity, and rigid pacing (exactly 5 minutes per passage) doesn't account for this variability. By working efficiently on easier passages, you create a time buffer that reduces stress and allows you to think more carefully about challenging questions. However, don't rush through easier passages so quickly that you make careless errors—the time you save isn't worth it if you miss questions you should have gotten right. Aim for efficient accuracy, not just speed.

Managing Difficult Passages Strategically

When you encounter a particularly challenging passage—whether due to complex figures, unfamiliar terminology, or confusing experimental design—have a strategy for managing it without letting it derail your entire section. First, recognize that not all questions within a passage are equally difficult. Even in a challenging passage, there are usually 2-3 straightforward questions that ask for simple data reading or basic trends. Tackle those first to secure easy points. For genuinely difficult questions that would require extensive time, consider strategic guessing—if you've spent 60 seconds on a question and still aren't sure, make your best guess and move on rather than spending 2-3 minutes agonizing over one question. You can also employ the strategy of saving one passage for last—if you reach the final passage with only 3 minutes remaining, answer the easiest questions you can identify and guess on the rest rather than running out of time completely.

Example: Strategic Passage Selection

Your Science section contains:
- Passage 1: Research Summaries (3 experiments, dense text) - MEDIUM DIFFICULTY
- Passage 2: Data Representation (simple line graphs) - EASY
- Passage 3: Conflicting Viewpoints (lots of text) - HARD
- Passage 4: Data Representation (multiple tables) - EASY
- Passage 5: Research Summaries (2 experiments) - MEDIUM
- Passage 6: Data Representation (scatter plots) - MEDIUM

Optimal order: 2 → 4 → 6 → 1 → 5 → 3 (easy passages first, hardest last)

This ensures you secure maximum points on straightforward passages before tackling the time-consuming Conflicting Viewpoints passage.

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓ ✓Follow the optimal sequence: brief intro reading → examine all figures → skim procedures → answer questions
  • ✓ ✓Prioritize figures and tables over text—60-70% of questions can be answered primarily from visual data
  • ✓ ✓Use the figure-first approach for Data Representation and most Research Summaries passages
  • ✓ ✓Read text more carefully for Conflicting Viewpoints passages to understand different scientific perspectives
  • ✓ ✓Systematically analyze every figure: variables, units, scale, trends, and legend/key
  • ✓ ✓Identify relationships between variables: positive, negative, linear, non-linear, or exponential
  • ✓ ✓Avoid common mistakes: confusing x/y variables, misreading scales, ignoring units, and wrong legend interpretation
  • ✓ ✓Complete passages in strategic order—identify and tackle your strongest passage types first
  • ✓ ✓Bank time by working efficiently on easier passages, giving yourself extra time for complex ones
  • ✓ ✓Don't spend more than 60 seconds struggling with one question—guess and move on if necessary

The ACT Science section tests your ability to analyze scientific data, interpret graphs and tables, understand experimental design, evaluate competing hypotheses, and draw evidence-based conclusions. Unlike traditional science tests that assess memorized content knowledge, the ACT Science section primarily measures your scientific reasoning and data interpretation skills. With only 35 minutes to answer 40 questions across 6-7 passages, you must work quickly and efficiently while maintaining accuracy. This lesson introduces the fundamental structure of the Science section, explains what skills are actually being tested, and provides a roadmap for approaching this challenging but highly manageable section of the ACT.

1. Understanding the Science Section Format

The ACT Science section is the fourth and final section of the test, consisting of 6-7 passages with 40 total questions. You have exactly 35 minutes to complete all questions, which translates to approximately 5 minutes per passage. Understanding the structure, passage types, and time constraints is essential for developing an effective strategy that maximizes your score.

Section Timing and Passage Distribution

The Science section always follows the same predictable format: 35 minutes total, 6-7 passages, and 40 questions. The number of questions per passage varies depending on the passage type—most passages have 5-6 questions, but the Conflicting Viewpoints passage typically has 7 questions. This means you have approximately 52.5 seconds per question, but in practice, you need to account for the time required to read and understand passages, study figures, and analyze data. The strict time limit makes the Science section one of the most time-pressured parts of the ACT. Many students report that their biggest challenge is finishing all passages within the allotted time, which is why developing efficient reading and data analysis strategies is crucial.

The Three Passage Types

Every Science section contains three distinct passage types: Data Representation (2-3 passages with 5 questions each), Research Summaries (3-4 passages with 6 questions each), and Conflicting Viewpoints (1 passage with 7 questions). Data Representation passages present scientific information through graphs, tables, and diagrams with minimal text, testing your ability to extract and analyze data. Research Summaries passages describe one or more experiments, testing your understanding of experimental design, variables, and results. Conflicting Viewpoints passages present two or more scientists or students discussing different hypotheses or theories about the same phenomenon, testing your ability to compare and contrast scientific perspectives. Recognizing these passage types immediately helps you adjust your reading strategy and know what to expect.

Content Areas Covered

Science passages cover topics from biology, chemistry, physics, and Earth/space sciences. Topics might include genetics, ecology, chemical reactions, atomic structure, motion and forces, electricity, geology, meteorology, astronomy, and more. However, the ACT does not expect you to have memorized extensive science content—nearly all information needed to answer questions is provided in the passage itself. The section primarily tests your ability to interpret data, understand experimental methods, and apply basic scientific reasoning rather than recall specific facts. That said, having a general familiarity with basic science concepts (like understanding what pH measures, knowing that temperature affects reaction rates, or recognizing common scientific units) can help you work more efficiently.

Scoring and Performance Expectations

Your Science section score is based on the number of questions you answer correctly, called your raw score (0-40), which is then converted to a scaled score from 1-36. The conversion table varies slightly from test to test to account for difficulty differences, but generally, missing 2-3 questions can still yield a score in the 33-35 range, while missing 6-8 questions typically results in a score around 28-30. There is no penalty for wrong answers, so you should always guess if you're running out of time. The Science section is often considered one of the most improvable sections of the ACT because success depends more on test-taking strategies and data interpretation skills than on extensive content knowledge. Students who initially struggle with timing often see significant score improvements after learning efficient passage navigation techniques and question-answering strategies.

Example: Section Breakdown

Typical Science section structure:
- Data Representation passages: 2-3 passages × 5 questions = 10-15 questions
- Research Summaries passages: 3-4 passages × 6 questions = 18-24 questions
- Conflicting Viewpoints passage: 1 passage × 7 questions = 7 questions

Total: 6-7 passages with 40 questions in 35 minutes. Recommended pacing: 5 minutes per passage, with flexibility to spend more time on complex passages and less on straightforward ones.

2. What the Science Section Actually Tests

Despite its name, the ACT Science section is better understood as a scientific reasoning test rather than a traditional science knowledge test. The section assesses three main skill categories: Interpretation of Data, Scientific Investigation, and Evaluation of Models, Inferences, and Experimental Results. Understanding these skill categories helps you recognize what each question is asking and how to approach it strategically.

Interpretation of Data (40-50% of questions)

Interpretation of Data questions test your ability to read graphs and tables, identify trends, extract specific values, and interpolate or extrapolate data. You might be asked to determine what temperature corresponds to a specific pressure value from a graph, identify whether two variables have a positive or inverse relationship, or predict what would happen if an experiment continued beyond the data shown. These questions require careful attention to axis labels, units, scales, and legends. Common question stems include: "According to Figure 1, what was the pH when temperature was 40°C?", "Based on Table 2, as concentration increased, reaction rate:", or "If the experiment had continued, the mass at 60 seconds would most likely have been:". Success on these questions comes from methodically reading data representations and avoiding careless errors like misreading scales or confusing which variable is which.

Scientific Investigation (20-30% of questions)

Scientific Investigation questions test your understanding of experimental design, variables, controls, and scientific methodology. You need to identify which variables were manipulated (independent variables), which were measured (dependent variables), which were held constant (control variables), and what the purpose of specific experimental procedures was. Questions might ask: "Which variable was directly manipulated by the researchers?", "What was the purpose of Trial 1?", "Which of the following would be the best way to extend this experiment?", or "What hypothesis was being tested in Experiment 2?" These questions assess whether you understand how scientific experiments are structured and how scientists test hypotheses systematically. Strong performance requires understanding the logic behind experimental design and recognizing the difference between correlation and causation.

Evaluation of Models, Inferences, and Experimental Results (30-40% of questions)

Evaluation questions test your ability to draw conclusions, make inferences, analyze competing viewpoints, and evaluate whether evidence supports a hypothesis. These questions require higher-order thinking and often involve synthesizing information from multiple sources within a passage. You might be asked: "Based on the results of Experiments 1 and 2, which conclusion is best supported?", "Which hypothesis is consistent with the data in Table 3?", "Student 1 would most likely agree with which statement?", or "What additional information would help determine which theory is correct?" These questions are typically more challenging because they require you to go beyond simply reading data and instead think critically about what the data means, what assumptions underlie different viewpoints, and what logical conclusions can be drawn. Success requires careful reasoning and avoiding common pitfalls like choosing answers that sound plausible but aren't actually supported by the passage.

The Minimal Role of Outside Knowledge

One of the most important things to understand about the ACT Science section is that it requires minimal outside content knowledge. The vast majority of questions can be answered using only the information provided in the passage, figures, and tables. You might encounter 1-3 questions per test that require basic scientific knowledge (such as knowing that water boils at 100°C at standard pressure, understanding that photosynthesis produces oxygen, or recognizing common lab equipment), but these represent a very small percentage of total questions. In fact, trying to apply outside knowledge can sometimes lead you astray if you make assumptions that contradict the passage's specific setup. The best approach is to trust the passage and base your answers on what is explicitly stated or clearly implied by the data. Students with limited science coursework can still achieve excellent scores by focusing on data interpretation and reasoning skills rather than worrying about content gaps.

Example: Skill Category Breakdown

In a typical 40-question Science section:
- 16-20 questions test Interpretation of Data (reading graphs, identifying trends, extracting values)
- 8-12 questions test Scientific Investigation (experimental design, variables, controls)
- 12-16 questions test Evaluation (drawing conclusions, analyzing viewpoints, making inferences)

Knowing this distribution helps you understand where to focus your practice and what skills matter most for a high score. The majority of questions test data interpretation and evaluation skills rather than memorized science facts.

3. Common Misconceptions About the Science Section

Many students approach the Science section with incorrect assumptions that hinder their performance. Understanding and correcting these misconceptions is crucial for developing an effective strategy and avoiding common pitfalls that prevent students from reaching their scoring potential.

Misconception #1: You Need Extensive Science Knowledge

The most pervasive misconception is that the Science section tests how much biology, chemistry, and physics you've learned in school. In reality, the section tests scientific reasoning and data interpretation skills, not memorized content. Students who have taken Advanced Placement science courses don't necessarily score higher than students with basic science coursework if they haven't developed strong graph-reading and analytical skills. The passage provides all necessary context, definitions, and background information. Your job is to extract relevant information and apply logical reasoning, not recall obscure scientific facts. In fact, overthinking questions by trying to apply outside knowledge often leads students to incorrect answers when they should simply trust what the passage explicitly states. Focus on developing strong data analysis skills rather than cramming science content.

Misconception #2: You Must Read Every Word of Text

Another common mistake is reading Science passages the same way you'd read a Reading passage—carefully working through every sentence from beginning to end. While this approach ensures you don't miss anything, it's often too slow for the Science section's time constraints. Many successful test-takers adopt a strategic skimming approach: quickly reading the introduction to understand the general topic, focusing primarily on figures and tables, and only reading detailed text when needed to answer specific questions. The figures often contain the most important information, while paragraphs of text frequently just explain procedures in more detail than necessary. Learning to prioritize visual data over lengthy descriptions can save significant time. However, this doesn't mean ignoring text entirely—you need to read enough to understand what was studied and what the variables represent, but you don't need to memorize every procedural detail.

Misconception #3: Harder Science Topics Mean Harder Questions

Students often feel intimidated when they see passages about unfamiliar or complex-sounding topics like "polymerase chain reaction" or "superconductivity." However, passage topic complexity does not correlate with question difficulty. A passage about a sophisticated physics concept might have straightforward questions that simply ask you to read values from a graph, while a passage about a simple experiment with plants might have challenging questions that require synthesizing information from multiple trials. The ACT deliberately uses technical-sounding topics to test whether you can stay focused and confident when faced with unfamiliar material. Don't let intimidating vocabulary or advanced-sounding topics psyche you out. The questions are designed to be answerable regardless of your prior knowledge of the specific topic. Stay calm, focus on the data, and trust that all necessary information is provided.

Misconception #4: The Passages Must Be Completed in Order

Many students assume they must work through Science passages in the order they appear, but this is not a requirement. In fact, strategic passage selection can improve both your score and confidence. Some students find Data Representation passages faster and easier because they focus primarily on graphs with minimal text, so they tackle those first to bank time for more complex passages. Others prefer starting with Research Summaries because they find the experimental format more intuitive. Still others save the Conflicting Viewpoints passage for last because it has the most text and different question types. You can also preview passages quickly and identify which ones look most straightforward based on figure complexity and text length. Experiment during practice to find an order that maximizes your efficiency. Just be careful to bubble answers in the correct spots on your answer sheet when you skip around.

Example: Correcting Misconceptions in Practice

Before: "I need to read every word carefully and I'm worried because I haven't taken AP Chemistry yet."

After: "I'll focus primarily on the figures and tables, skim the text for context, and trust that all information I need is in the passage. My score depends on data interpretation skills, not memorized content."

This mindset shift alone can lead to significant time savings and reduced anxiety, allowing you to work more efficiently and confidently through Science passages.

4. Building Your Science Section Foundation

Success on the ACT Science section requires developing a systematic approach that combines efficient passage navigation, strong data interpretation skills, strategic time management, and focused practice. This section introduces foundational concepts and habits that will support your improvement across all Science question types.

Developing a Passage Attack Strategy

Every high-scoring Science student develops a consistent passage approach that they apply to every passage. A typical effective strategy involves: (1) quickly reading the introduction to understand what phenomenon or question is being studied, (2) examining all figures and tables to understand what variables are being measured and what trends are visible, (3) skimming any experimental descriptions to identify how trials differ from each other, and (4) moving to the questions, referring back to specific parts of the passage as needed. This approach prioritizes the most important information (the data itself) while avoiding getting bogged down in procedural details. However, you should experiment with variations during practice to find what works best for your reading style and strengths. Some students prefer reading questions first to know what to look for, while others find this disruptive. Find your optimal approach through deliberate practice.

Mastering Figure and Table Analysis

Since the majority of Science questions require you to extract or analyze data from graphs, tables, and diagrams, developing strong figure-reading skills is essential. When you look at any figure, immediately identify: (1) what variables are being shown (check axis labels and table headers), (2) what units are being used (meters, seconds, grams, etc.), (3) what scale is being used (does the axis start at zero or some other value?), (4) what relationships or trends are visible (do values increase, decrease, or stay constant?), and (5) what different lines or symbols represent (check the legend). Practice reading figures actively by asking yourself these questions for every graph or table you encounter. Also train yourself to spot common pitfalls like logarithmic scales, multiple y-axes, or unusual units that could cause misinterpretation.

Understanding Variables and Experimental Design Basics

A significant portion of Science questions test your understanding of how experiments are designed and controlled. You need to be comfortable identifying independent variables (what the researcher changes), dependent variables (what the researcher measures), and control variables (what the researcher keeps the same). For example, if an experiment tests how different fertilizers affect plant growth, the fertilizer type is the independent variable, plant height is the dependent variable, and factors like water amount, sunlight, and temperature should be control variables. You should also understand why scientists run control groups (to provide a baseline for comparison), why they repeat trials multiple times (to ensure results are reliable and not due to chance), and how to distinguish between correlation and causation. These fundamental concepts appear repeatedly across Science passages.

Time Management and Practice Strategies

Improving your Science score requires deliberate practice with a focus on both accuracy and speed. Start by working on individual passages untimed to ensure you understand how to analyze data and answer questions correctly. Once your accuracy is consistently high (80%+ correct), begin adding time pressure by setting a 5-minute timer per passage. Track which passage types and question types give you the most trouble, and dedicate extra practice to those areas. When reviewing practice questions, don't just check whether you got them right or wrong—carefully review the reasoning behind each answer, figure out why wrong answers are incorrect, and identify what clues in the passage you should have noticed. Also practice on full-length Science sections to build stamina and ensure your strategy works under realistic testing conditions. Many students find that their Science score improves more rapidly than other sections once they understand the underlying skills being tested and develop efficient strategies.

Example: Building Your Science Practice Plan

Week 1-2: Master individual passage types untimed. Focus on Data Representation passages first (simplest), then Research Summaries, then Conflicting Viewpoints.

Week 3-4: Practice full Science sections with timing (35 minutes). Identify your weak passage types and question types.

Week 5-6: Target your weaknesses with focused practice. Review every question you miss to understand the reasoning.

Week 7-8: Take full-length practice ACTs to build stamina and refine your pacing strategy. Adjust your approach based on results.

This structured progression builds skills systematically while maintaining motivation through visible progress.

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓ ✓The Science section has 35 minutes for 6-7 passages and 40 questions—approximately 5 minutes per passage
  • ✓ ✓The section tests scientific reasoning and data interpretation skills, not memorized science content
  • ✓ ✓Three passage types appear: Data Representation (2-3), Research Summaries (3-4), and Conflicting Viewpoints (1)
  • ✓ ✓Focus primarily on figures and tables—they contain most of the important information for answering questions
  • ✓ ✓Questions test three skills: Interpretation of Data (40-50%), Scientific Investigation (20-30%), and Evaluation (30-40%)
  • ✓ ✓Nearly all questions can be answered using only information provided in the passage—outside knowledge is rarely needed
  • ✓ ✓You don't need to read every word—strategic skimming focused on data and key concepts is more efficient
  • ✓ ✓Passages don't have to be completed in order—identify and tackle your strongest passage types first
  • ✓ ✓Master figure analysis by identifying variables, units, scales, trends, and what different symbols represent
  • ✓ ✓The Science section is highly improvable through strategic practice focused on data interpretation and time management

sampleData.title: Identifying the Correct Transition
sampleData.problem_text: From a distance, the ocean looked pretty calm today even though a storm had arrived last night. [Transition], the scene was much more chaotic with big waves and strong riptides.

solution_steps.text: Read the context: First sentence says "from a distance" the ocean looked calm.
The second sentence describes chaos with big waves and riptides.
We need a transition that contrasts "from a distance" with what's happening closer.
"Up close" is the logical opposite of "from a distance" and properly connects these contrasting observations.

sampleData.answer_explanation: "Up close" creates a clear contrast with "from a distance" in the previous sentence.

sampleData.title: Pronoun-Antecedent Agreement
sampleData.problem_text: Each of the students must submit their research paper by Friday.

solution_steps.text: Identify the antecedent: "Each" (singular, indefinite pronoun)
"Their" is plural and doesn't agree with singular "each."
Use "his or her" to match the singular antecedent.
Words like "each," "every," "either," "neither" are singular.

sampleData.answer_explanation: "Each" is singular, so use "his or her" instead of "their."

sampleData.title: Parallel Structure with Correlative Conjunctions
sampleData.problem_text: The restaurant is known not only for its excellent food but also having great service.

choices.text: but also for its great service.
but also they have great service.

solution_steps.text: Identify correlative conjunctions: "not only...but also"
After "not only": "for its excellent food" (prepositional phrase)
After "but also": "having great service" (gerund phrase) - not parallel!
Option B uses "for its great service" matching the structure after "not only."

sampleData.answer_explanation: Make structures parallel after "not only" and "but also" - both should be prepositional phrases.

sampleData.title: Apostrophe Usage
sampleData.problem_text: The childrens' toys were scattered throughout the playroom.

solution_steps.text: Identify the possessive: toys belonging to children.
"Children" is already plural (irregular plural, not ending in -s).
For plural nouns not ending in -s, add 's (not s').
Correct form is "children's" with apostrophe before the s.

sampleData.answer_explanation: For irregular plurals like "children," use apostrophe + s: children's.

sampleData.title: Mixed Grammar Review
sampleData.problem_text: Neither the teachers nor the principal were aware of the students plan to organize a surprise assembly.

choices.text: was aware of the students' plan
were aware of the students' plan
was aware of the student's plan

solution_steps.text: With "neither...nor," the verb agrees with the closest subject: "principal" (singular).
However, "students plan" needs an apostrophe for possession.
Multiple students = "students'" (plural possessive).
Choice C fixes the possessive while maintaining correct verb agreement.

sampleData.answer_explanation: Use "students'" for plural possessive and match verb to nearest subject.
